fixed_lines: if (newRecord && (c < 0x20 || c > 0x21 && c < 0x23 || c > 0x2B && c < 0x2D || c > 0x7E)) {
bug_description:
Bug Description:

Bug ID: 14 
Project: CSV 
Bug Type: Syntax, Semantic, and Standard Failure (SL SH SF) 

Location of the bug: 
The bug is located in the `printAndQuote` function within the `if` statement found in the `MINIMAL` case. 

Problem:
The comparison operands within the if condition (c < '0' || c > '9' && c < 'A' || c > 'Z' && c < 'a' || c > 'z') have caused a junit.framework.AssertionFailedError. It expected '<[\]>' but got '<["\"]>', showing wrong assertion and a mismatch between the expected and actual result. Hence, the code has failed the unit test.

Details: 
This bug is causing an error because it checks whether `c` falls outside of three different numeric ranges. It seems, the standard used to determine these ranges, RFC4180 - https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4180 'TEXTDATA' definition, has been misunderstood or implemented incorrectly.

Steps to Reproduce the Bug:

1. Initialize a new object and a CharSequence.
2. Call the function printAndQuote() with appropriate parameters.
3. The function should enter the 'MINIMAL' switch case if the QuoteMode equals 'MINIMAL'.
4. In the if condition, if `newRecord` is true and if `c` falls in the specified range, `quote` should be set as true. This condition causes the fail as the range is set improperly.

Fix:
The bug is fixed by changing the numerical comparisons back to hexadecimal comparisons as per the RFC4180 standard definition of 'TEXTDATA' in the 'MINIMAL' case of the switch statement. The correction seems to adjust the range checks on the character values to ensure they're within the valid ASCII ranges according to the specification.

The fixed if condition becomes: if(newRecord && (c < 0x20 || c > 0x21 && c < 0x23 || c > 0x2B && c < 0x2D || c > 0x7E)) { quote = true; }. 

This modification should now check `c` correctly for whether `c` falls outside of the proper standard ASCII ranges. This directly addresses the AssertionFailedError and should now pass the relevant test.
